Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High Resolution Mapping Raman Microprobe for Research and Teaching
Award.AbstractNarration:
1428857
Elwood-Madden

This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program grant supports acquisition of an imaging Raman microscope to allow for non-destructive, high resolution (micron scale) and time resolved studies of geological, biological, environmental, archeological, and engineered materials. The Raman microscope would have automated x-y-z translatable stage, dual-wavelength laser excitation sources, and variable temperature (-196 to 600 degree C) sample chamber. Specific studies that would take advantage of the Raman system would include in situ observations of fluid alteration and weathering processes at mineral surfaces, studies of gas clathrate formation and dissociation processes in permafrost and deep-sea environments, studies of biologically mediated material corrosion processes, and trace metal speciation and oxidation/reduction mechanisms in natural and contaminated systems. The instrument would serve faculty and their students across several departments at Oklahoma and the PIs intend to engage underrepresented students in experiential learning through an extant Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics program at the University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project established a High Resolution Mapping Raman user center facility for the University of Oklahoma and other users. We purchased a Renishaw InVia Mapping High Resolution Raman Spectrometer that has enabled numerous research projects in geology, microbiology, engineering, and health sciences.    We hired a Raman User Center Research Scientist who has conducted a series of group training sessions and implemented a business plan for the user facility. The Raman User Center Research Scientist has trained over 30 faculty and students in Raman spectroscopy and over 20 scientists have used the instrument to support studies in planetary mineralogy and geochemistry, chemical weathering, igneous petrology, geomicrobiology, microbial corrosion, groundwater quality, oncology, and pharmaceutical development.  These efforts have led to a clearer understanding of iron oxide mineralogy on Mars, targeted the mineralogical source of hexavalent chromium in the Central Oklahoma Aquifer, developed new techniques for measuring solutes in high salinity brines, investigated how microbial biofilms influence corrosion processes within pipelines, and characterized materials for pharmaceutical development. This research has to date yielded 10 conference abstracts and 5 peer-reviewed publications, with additional publications expected in the near future. The instrument has also been used to support undergraduate research through our Geowriting technical writing course. Fifteen undergraduates used the instrument to collect original data that they then used to write a journal-style manuscript and prepare conference-style talks and posters.
